",,,1,Partitioning & Brand Domain launches,,,,,"

On November 1, we’re launching two exciting new features that’ll change the way advanced marketing teams interact with HubSpot: partitioning and brand domains.

Partitioning is the ability to separate your assets by team. We’ve always had database partitioning (e.g. only the LatAM sales team can access LatAm leads)
column2:
this November, we’re launching page partitioning (e.g. only the partner marketing team can access and edit partner-specific landing pages). In the coming months, we plan on launching full content partitioning --- emails, CTAs, forms, and all the rest.

Those partitions work great on a customer’s main domain. If they want to apply partitions to additional brands, that'
column3:
s where brand domains come into play. A brand domain is a $700 add-on that extends Enterprise features - including partitioning - to additional root domains (e.g. hubspot.com vs. inbound.com.)

As a note, we need to be clear that this is not a replacement for an additional URL. In other words, if you want to run two businesses in one portal, an Enterprise portal plus a Brand Domain likely won’t suffice at this time.

What is a brand domain?

A brand domain is a root domain, like “hubspot” or “inbound.”

The brand domains add-on costs $700/month. It enables the following, on an additional brand domain:

  • Hosting content. E.g. creating pages on “inbound.com,” in addition to “hubspot.com.”

  • Reporting. E.g. separating traffic analytics for “inbound.com” vs “hubspot.com.”

  • Permissions on domains. E.g. Team X can publish pages  on “hubspot.com,” but not “inbound.com”

In other words, Marketing Hub Enterprise enables you to do these three things for one brand domain (e.g. hubspot) and any subdomains (e.g. blog.hubspot.com). As soon as a company wants to expand these three things to an an additional brand domain (like inbound), they’ll buy the add-on.

Note that, with the change, as of November 1, Marketing Hub Enterprise portals will only be able to host content on one root domain (and any subdomains/TLDs). Hosting on additional root domains will require the purchase of the Brand Domains add-on. This applies to both new and existing customers. Read on for more info on grandfathering.

What’s the grandparenting policy?

All existing Enterprise portals will get partitioning on November 1st without an increase in price.  As we mentioned above, this is the ability to separate web pages, blog posts, and landing pages by team. After November 1st, if customers want to extend functionality to additional brands they will need to pay for those additional brand domains.  E.g. HubSpot wanting to manage Inbound.com in our core portal 53 which is used for HubSpot.com.

We’ll be working with existing customers that already host content on multiple brand domains inside a single Enterprise portal to ensure that they’re not negatively impacted by the release of this functionality and our monetization of additional brand domains. If you’re in services, we’ll work with you directly in the next two weeks to prepare for conversations with these customers.

What’s next?

If you’re in Sales, Alnoor and Lexi put up a super helpful How to Sell page, and will be running a “Demo like a Pro” next week. Reach out to #sales-questions in Slack with any questions.

If you’re in Services, Annie & Stephen have set up trainings for next week. We’ll walk you through all the nuances, the product itself, the customer communications plan, and any scenarios you might come up against with customers. We’d encourage you to check out the Wiki link above, and to watch the video on the Wiki page. Reach out to #cslearnandgrow on Slack with any questions.

",,,5,How to use HubSpot's apex redirection,,,,,"

Engineering recently built us an apex redirection service. Here's some information about how this works.

Since customers can only connect their subdomains to HubSpot using CNAME records, redirecting their apex domain (domain.com) to their main website (www.domain.com) can sometimes be problematic. Major providers like Godaddy offer domain forwarding (which points the apex domain to an IP address to do the redirect), but some DNS providers don't offer this functionality. And since it's not usually possible to create a CNAME record for the apex domain, if a customer with an incompatible DNS provider wanted to move their whole site to the COS, the only solution for redirecting the apex domain to their www subdomain was to move providers. This isn't a great solution and so our Engineering team built us a redirection service.

What’s the change?
The new analytics pipeline --- which is faster and more reliable for our customers, and much more flexible for us --- will be rolled out to several HubSpot tools over the next few weeks.
We have over 30,000 marketing customers. Each customer tracks a slew of analytics with HubSpot,
column2: from CTA clicks to pageviews to form submissions to event completions and beyond. Think, for just a second, about how much data that represents.

column1: The analytics pipeline is the system that tracks, processes, counts, and stores all that data. Up until now, the analytics pipeline that we have in place has done a pretty good job of dealing with the huge volume of input & output. That said, as HubSpot's user base grows, and our customers scale their businesses (e.g. publish even more pages & blogs, getting more visitors), we need an analytics system that's built to support such growth.
With that in mind, we've spent the last year and a half building a brand new pipeline from the ground up, to be more scalable and resilient, and to grow with our customers.
You saw the first signs of that new system in the last few months, with a new web analytics dashboard that brought bounce rate, time on page, device metrics, and more into HubSpot for the first time.
With this change, that new analytics engine makes its way into several other HubSpot tools.
Here’s what customers can look forward to with the new engine in place:

• Data will refresh faster --- updating every twenty minutes on average, instead of every three hours --- so you’ll be able to measure the success of your strategy (and pivot accordingly) that much quicker.

• Website metrics will more accurately reflect the way your visitors actually interact with a website. That manifests itself in several ways. One example: session timeouts. Your visitors read your content in spurts. They’ll come to your site, peruse a few pages, head out to their lunch break, then a meeting, then come back and pick up where they left off. The rebuilt analytics engine in HubSpot accounts for those on-and-off interactions in a much more structured way, with sessions that expire after 30 minutes of visitor inactivity.
• “Analyze” section of website, landing pages, and blog
• Detail pages of website, landing pages, blog, CTAs, and forms
If the data does change, what will change?

The aggregate data --- totals for views, submissions, clicks, and more --- will go virtually untouched. If data does change, it’s more likely to occur where those totals are broken down into “buckets.” A prime example: the breakdown by source, in the details of a specific page. Here are two specific ways that data might improve with the rebuilt engine, resulting in an update to the numbers in a page’s source breakdown:

• A visitor finds your site via organic search, reads a few blog posts, then leaves the website. Within 30 minutes, she starts thinking about all that interesting content she just read, goes directly back to the website, and converts on one of your forms. With the previous version of the analytics engine --- which lacked the idea of a thirty-minute timeout on a session --- that submission would have been attributed to direct traffic, even though it originated from organic search. With the rebuilt engine, that submission would be attributed (more accurately) to organic instead. In this case (and similar ones), you might see direct submissions on your landing pages be more accurately recategorized into other sources.

• You import a list from your last trade show. One of the people on that list loved the interaction, Googles your company name two weeks later, finds your site, and converts on a form. But, in this particular case, you’ve set that form not to use cookie tracking, so that it creates a unique contact with each and every submission. With that setting in mind, their browser isn’t passing the right data to HubSpot, for our systems to track the pages they’re viewing along the way. In the new way of calculating analytics metrics, we can often infer their last touch source (in this case, Google) from the the form submission itself, even without being able to track the pages viewed along the way. In this case (and similar ones), you might see “offline source” submissions on your landing pages be more accurately recategorized into other online sources.

With the update, you might notice minor changes to the values in a few analytics-related contact properties. Specifically, Time of Last Visit, Number of Visits, and Average Page views may change --- to a more accurate value --- with the new data engine. A specific example of how the new engine might improve the values in these fields:

Let's say a contact visited your site on a Friday afternoon, then left that tab open on his desktop over the weekend, came back to the site on Monday, and explored a separate product line. The ""old"" engine --- without the concept of a 30-minute timeout --- would see this as a single visit. With that in mind, the ""Time of Last Visit"" property would show Friday afternoon. With the new engine, the properties would more accurately reflect the visitor's activity. ""Number of Visits"" would be two (since the visitor did, in fact, come to the site on two separate occasions) and ""Time of Last Visit"" would show Monday.

A CRM mobile app for Android. View all your HubSpot contacts and company timelines and update them with notes, activities, and tasks from your favorite Android device.

Sales doesn’t always happen from behind a desk. If you’re a field rep --- or even if you’re not --- parts of your process take you on the road. Whether a dinner with a prospect, an in-person demo with a lead, a trade show, or even a busy morning commute, your sales process needs to travel with you.
With that in mind, at INBOUND 2016, your HubSpot CRM app on iOS got a fresh new (all-in-one) look. Then, in February, HubSpot CRM made its way to your iPad.

Today, Android joins the party: the most critical parts of your sales process are now a thumb tap away. With the release of the HubSpot CRM app for Android, you can now view and create records, track your deal pipeline, and catch up on your tasks, all from your favorite device. Your sales process, in your pocket.
As an added bonus, the Android app includes two brand new features:

• HubSpot Caller ID. With HubSpot Caller ID, every time you make or receive a call, an at-a-glance version of that contact’s timeline will display on your phone automatically. What’s the most recent email they clicked? Which content did you send to them last? What did you discuss on your last call? Get the context you need to make better connections with your prospects and customers.

• Business card scanning. We all know that feeling. Walking home from a trade show or industry event with a pocket full of business cards. Our goal: follow up in a personal way with each and every connection. The reality: most of those cards never see the light of day.

    With today’s update, you can turn business cards into CRM contacts faster than you can say “we’ll be in touch.”

    One thumb tap. One contact created. No extra expenses, no manual entry, no third-party integrations, no hassle.
Of all smartphones sold in Q4 of 2016, a whopping 82% ran Android (compared to 17% running iOS). While you (and everyone you know) might have an iPhone, the market reflects a different world.

Not having an Android app doesn’t simply limit the individual HubSpot CRM/Sales users that run Android --- it impacts their entire teams. If you’re a manager, and even one or two reps on your team have Android phones, how can you choose a CRM that doesn’t have an Android app?
What can you do with the mobile app?
• View, create, and edit contacts, companies and deals, and tasks.
• HubSpot Caller ID - view an at-a-glance timeline in the context of an incoming or outgoing call.
• Scan business cards. Take a picture of a business card and it’ll automatically create a contact in HubSpot CRM.

What is it?

In HubSpot, you’ll now see a floating notification in real time at the top right of your screen when one of your teammates mentions you in an activity on a HubSpot CRM record.

Why does it matter?

We’re passionate about driving success for you and your team. With today’s update, it’s easier for you to collaborate with your team in HubSpot by presenting you with real time updates directly where you work.How does it work?

The floating notification will contain a short preview of the activity text and display for 8 seconds:

  • Click on the floating notification to go to the relevant contact record and see the full context of the activity where you were mentioned.

  • If you miss the notification, don’t worry --- you can see the notification detail by clicking on the notification bell icon in the HubSpot navigation bar.

  • If you have email notifications turned on for mentions, you will still get the notification via email too.

  • To turn off floating notifications, hover over the floating notification, click the ellipsis, then click ‘Don’t show me these again’. These are also configurable in your notification preferences.

8,Security,,,,24,"In case a server housing our data goes down, what's the recovery time?",,,,,"

HubSpot primarily relies on infrastructure redundancy across multiple datacenters availability zones. Data is replicated and backed up in multiple durable data-stores. All infrastrcture, from web hosting to backend systems have a fully redundant web and database infrastructure in at least 3 zones of our primary hosting provider. Many data types needed in case of catastrophic failure are also replicated to other providers to ensure multi-vendor redundancy.

If an entire region were to become unavailable, infrastructure is designed to be rapidly and repeatedly de-provisioned and re-provisioned automatically. New instances would be automatically provisioned and backups restored (if needed) in order to provide as seamless a transition as possible.

In the case of individual servers, our standard infrastructure management activities provision and deprovision hundreds of servers daily without any customer impact. The redundancy and automated failover are happening continually without any of our users being able to notice.
Above answer provided by the Security team.

8,Security,,,,25,How often do you backup our data or would that be our responsibility?,,,,,"

HubSpot ensures data is replicated and backed up in multiple durable data-stores and retention periods depend on the nature of the data. The following policies have been implemented and enforced for data-protection: Customer (production) data is backed up leveraging multiple online replicas of data for immediate data protection however, point-in-time copies are also made for business continuity and restoration. All production databases have no less than 1 primary (master) and 1 replica (slave) copy of the data live at any given point in time. 7 days worth of backups are kept on any database in the same facility for local restoration. Replicas are taken and stored to a secondary facility or service no less often than daily and where practicable, real time replication is be used. All production data sets are stored on a distributed file storage facility like Amazon's S3.

8,Security,,,,26,"If we hire external pen testers, are we required to let you know?",,,,,"

The HubSpot Terms of Service prohibits vulnerability scanning or penetration testing against the HubSpot products. Unauthorized vulnerability scanning outside of a controlled environment can create risks to your portal in the context of inadvertently changing content or having your access to it blocked, among other risks. The restriction in the Terms of Service exists to help ensure that you have a positive experience with our products and that we're able to quickly identify and support your requests and questions. In order to ensure the products and customers' data is safe, the HubSpot security team performs daily vulnerability scanning and quarterly penetration testing. Vulnerabilities and their impacts are identified and resolved on a constant basis, in a controlled environment, and as part of HubSpot's rapid development lifecycle.

For customers who would like to test the protections built into the HubSpot platform using a fully-featured free trial, it is possible to test within the guidelines of our bug bounty program. For more info about HubSpot bug bounty and the guidelines, please visit https://bugcrowd.com/hubspot
Above answer provided by the Security Team.

When you purchase a standard SSL certificate, it gets installed on a server and encrypts the connection between your visitors browser and the web-server. When you purchase an SSL pack it is configured into our content delivery network so that regardless of where your traffic comes from, and the amount of traffic you get it will be encrypted using SSL. There are two separate but interdependent levels of indirection to consider here. The first is what IP address a DNS name ultimately resolves to. The second is what the server on that IP address does.
Remember that when you type a URL into a browser, the first thing that happens is a DNS lookup. Usually, that's handled by the operating system – not the browser itself.

So your browser will ask the OS, ""what is the address of example.com?"" The OS will look up the record, and if it gets a CNAME, will look up that record, until it finds an A record. The OS then responds to the browser with an answer.
Your browser then opens a TCP connection to that IP address:
If a http:// URL, it connects to port 80, then issues a HTTP request.
If a https:// URL, it connects to port 443, establishes a TLS/SSL connection (which means validating certificates), then issues a HTTP request over the secure channel.
Only at this point can HTTP redirection happen. The browser sends a request (GET /, and the server can respond with a 301 to any other URL.

Understand that ""subdomain redirection"" services offered by registrars are nothing more than a regular HTTP server that issues 301s. When you opt for a registrar's redirection option, they just set the A record of your domain's apex to a server they control, and that server tells browsers to go to www.example.com.

Since most registrars don't allow you upload a SSL certificate to their redirection server, browsers cannot establish the necessary secure connection to the server, and therefore they never issue a HTTP request. Thus, requests for https://example.com fail.
So why can't you just CNAME the apex? It is forbidden.

The domain system provides such a feature using the canonical name (CNAME) RR [Record Resource]. A CNAME RR identifies its owner name as an alias, and specifies the corresponding canonical name in the RDATA section of the RR. If a CNAME RR is present at a node, no other data should be present
column2: this ensures that the data for a canonical name and its aliases cannot be different. This rule also insures that a cached CNAME can be used without checking with an authoritative server for other RR types.

column1: The spec requires that a CNAME record be the only record for a given (sub)domain. This is at odds with the requirement of having a SOA record on the apex. (There are some efforts out there to change the specs to allow CNAME and SOA to coexist, but there are still many broken SMTP implementations that will be confused by the CNAME on a domain.)
You have the following options to get SSL working on the apex:

Use a third-party service that supports SSL on the redirect server. You'll likely pay for this.Here's one service. I would not recommend this route, since it takes the control of reliability out of your hands, and requires you to hand over the keys to your SSL certificate to someone who may or may not be trustworthy.

Run your own redirection server. Since the apex requires an A record, you'll need a static IP, which services like Heroku and AWS' ELB do not provide. So if you're in a cloud environment, it will be very difficult (if not impossible) to guarantee reliability. On the plus side, you retain control of your SSL keys.
Use a DNS host that allows you to set an alias. Point the alias to your Heroku domain/ELB/whatever. This is most likely the best option.
An alias is not technically a type of DNS record. Instead, it is a special configuration on the DNS host side that returns an A record from the result of another lookup. In other words:
Your OS issues a DNS request for example.com to your DNS host.
Your DNS host reads the internal alias configuration, and issues a DNS request for that domain. So if you have an alias set up for example.herokuapp.com, it would look up the Arecord of that domain.
The DNS host returns a simple A record with the IP(s) it got from the alias lookup.

With an alias record, you could point your apex to the same cloud load balancer that your www domain is CNAMEd to. Assuming you've set up SSL on the www domain, the naked domain will work just fine. At this point, it's your choice whether your app issues a redirect, or just serves your content directly over the naked domain.
For more information about this, ask Peter Manca

What is it?

We will no longer be offering phone Support for Starter-only subscriptions beginning on 5th September 2018. Starter-only subscribers will continue to have access to Support through email and chat as well as self-service channels like Community, Knowledge Base, and Academy.

Why?We’ve continued to add more features and options to the Starter product tier, while keeping the price low. We need to better align the support we can afford to give with the price these customers pay. This means we’ll be shifting the way we offer Support services to Starter-only subscribers. We also want to better align our Support offering with the way the majority of Starter-only customers choose to initially engage with and ultimately purchase our products – touchlessly and through self-service. By reducing phone volume from Starter-only customers, we will hopefully begin to shift our human resources upstream and improve the experience for our Professional, Enterprise, and Pro/Ent Growth Stack customers by reducing wait times and increasing the quality of our solutions.
